chapterTitle: Financial Statements, Taxes, and Cash Flow

columns.text: This exercise requires us to explain why changes in net working capital (CNW) and net capital spending may be negative.

Two of the three components of cash flows from assets are net capital spending and changes in working capital. **Capital spending** refers to cash paid and received for the sale and acquisition of fixed assets. On the other hand, **changes in net working capital** includes all cash flows from current assets and liabilities.

Presented below is the formula for capital spending. 

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Ending net fixed assets}&&\$\hspace{15pt}\text{xx}\\
\text{Less: Beginning fixed assets}&&\text{xx}\\
\text{Add: Depreciation}&&\underline{\hspace{20pt}\text{xx}}\\
\text{Net capital spending}&&\underline{\underline{\$\hspace{10pt}\text{XX}}}\\
\end{array}$$

A positive net capital spending will happen if the net fixed assets are more significant than its beginning balance. It means that an entity **pays more than it receives** from long-term investments. On the other hand, if the entity could **sell more assets than it purchased**, the result would be negative net capital expenditures.

The format of cash flows from changes in net working capital (NWC) is as follows:

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Ending net working capital}&&\$\hspace{15pt}\text{xx}\\
\text{Less: Beginning net working capital}&&\underline{\hspace{20pt}\text{xx}}\\
\text{Change in net working capital}&&\underline{\underline{\$\hspace{10pt}\text{XX}}}\\
\end{array}$$

A positive change in working capital means that the business **spends more money than it receives** from its current assets and liabilities. However, changes in net working capital will be negative if the entity **converts more cash** from its working capital.

Understanding the impacts of cash transactions on capital spending and net working capital is essential in analyzing the overall cash holdings of an entity. It ensures that the entity can maintain a sufficient cash balance for its operations regardless of cash received or spent.
This exercise requires us to explain about Net Working Capital and Capital Spending.

Lets first define Net Working Capital and Capital Spending.

**Net Working Capital** is the difference between a company's current assets and its current liabilities. While, **capital spending** is the amount of money of fund used by a company to acquire, upgrade, maintain or improve its fixed assets.

A company can have a negative change in NWC in a given year. This indicates that the company might require spending cash before selling and delivering its products or services. Furthermore, a negative change in NWC may result from poor liquidity caused by cash mismanagement. 

On the other hand, if it results from an efficient collection of receivables from customers and quick inventory turnover, the company should not be concerned.
Meanwhile, negative net capital spending indicates that more long-term assets were liquidated than purchased.
